div.p: 1. VI: Tuesday. At Sea. Latitude 43:16 Longitude 25:05. There were a number of heavy Squalls throughout the Night, and the swell was so great and the motion of the ship so convulsive, that I scarcely slept at-all, and not till after day-light. The cabin Passengers were at vingt-un till one. This Morning the sky was fair, but the wind at W.N.W. where it continued all day, moderate, and with fair weather, excepting a sudden squall of rain which passed over us while we were at dinner. My wife was so much recovered as to go upon deck for a couple of hours, but so weak that she fainted on returning to her State-Room. Charles was up the whole day, and none of the passengers Sea-sick. Coit told me they had split the fore top-gallant sail, and the gib to pieces yesterday, in carrying sail upon her to make her go ten knots; but he said the Sails were now repaired— I was able to write this Morning after Breakfast, but not so much as I ought. Played Chess after dinner with Mr Otis— The evening was moderate and fine; with the breaming or flashing of the water along-side of the ship, which portends Northerly winds. Air 61. Water 59.

2. V:45. The Night was tolerably tranquil, and the motion of the ship supportable. The course she kept W. & by S. and W. The Morning was mild and beautiful. The temperature of the Water and Air both 60. Before Noon it clouded up, and blew hard from N.W. with Squalls of Rain. The strong breeze continued the greater part of the day, but moderated as the Sun went down. The Evening was again moderate and pleasant, with breaming waters and a spangled sky, and frequent falling of atmospheric meteors. I regretted the want of Bode’s Uranographia to trace many of the minor Constellations. Jupiter has drawn into close conjunction with the first star of the Scorpion. They are all apparently higher above the horizon than when I observed them the first Night we came on board, by just as much as we have made of Southing; that is eight or nine degrees— And this Evening I saw most of the remarkable Stars in the tail of the Scorpion, which I had certainly not seen while I was in Europe, and had never before observed. They were still too low towards the horizon, and too much bedimmed by the haze of the atmosphere to be all distinctly seen— There was this day no Solar Observation The Longitude, reckoned by the Captain about 26. My wife was twice upon deck; once being obliged by the rain to return to the Cabin— She is yet extremely weak, and this afternoon and Evening was quite indisposed— We have frequent discussions at table after breakfast and dinner, upon various topics of Literature, Politics, Morals, Religion, and miscellaneous as they arise. In these Conversations, I am sometimes led perhaps to take too great a share. Dr Tillary and Mr Otis are the other principal interlocutors.— This afternoon I spent as usual with Mr Otis at Chess. In the Evening Dr Tillary discovered that a large portion of his Stores of liquor have vanished.— The suspicions are divided between some of the Steerage Passengers and an English fellow who waits in the Cabin as assistant to the Steward.

3. V:15. The first entirely fair day that we have had since we took our departure from the land’s end, but the wind was all the morning so nearly a head that we could steer not nearer than within two points of our course; and all the afternoon and evening directly ahead. The breeze was mild and pleasant; Water and Air both at 62: the motion of the ship so slight that I could write all the Morning, and lost little of it: none of the Passengers were sick; but the fractiousness of temper which a long continuance of adverse winds is apt to provoke upon a Sea-voyage begins to manifest itself; and I feel too much of it myself. Latitude 41:33. Longitude 28:05. We saw a whale, near under the bow of the ship; and so small that I at first took him for a porpoise. My wife was unwell all the Morning, but towards Evening so much recovered that she went for a short time upon deck. I played Chess in the afternoon with Mr Otis and was beaten— The debating Society in the Steerage had their meeting this Evening. Heavy fall of dew— The Deadlights excepting that of the Starboard Quarter were taken out.

4. IV:45. Independence day— John 14. In the Night there sprung up a stiff breeze: the top gallant-sails were taken in: we have had so much boisterous weather that the topsails are kept constantly reefed.— This Morning the sky was cloudless, but with a wind due West, blowing a Gale, and that haziness in the atmosphere, which generally accompany the strong west and Southwest winds.— The Air was at 64. Water at 62. A heavy head-sea, and the ship pitching so much that I wrote with great difficulty till breakfast, and not at all afterwards. The motion was even too violent to make it possible to play Chess. My wife was severely Sea-sick the whole day. Charles took to his bed before dinner, and Antoine was again unfitted
for all attendance. I read the voyages of Sinbad in Scott’s Translation of the Arabian Nights. No book that I read with great delight in my childhood has so entirely lost all interest to me, as these books of tales— They once afforded me some of the happiest hours of my life. I now find them inexpressibly dull— Much of the Story of Sinbad is evidently stolen from the Odyssey, and it surprizes me that writers to whom Homer was accessible and familiar, could not fill the seven voyages of Sinbad with a more variety of adventure, more diversity and individuality of characters, and more spirited Sentiment. Take away from Sinbad’s adventures the marvellous and impossible; and there is nothing left. What a difference, from the Odyssey!— We had our ship’s colours flying all day; and notwithstanding the Storm of wind, rain and thunder which came on about dinner time, we celebrated the day with such festivities, as our condition would admit. We kept at table from our dinner hour between 2 and 3 until dark—drank toasts and sung songs; and made passing merry— After a copious rain, the weather moderated; and the wind drew two or three points to the Northward.— The Head-Sea partly abated, & left us the prospect of a less unquiet Night than the last. Lat: 41:56. Long: 29:10.

5. VI: The wind died away in the Night nearly to a calm, which continued all this day; and although we made scarcely any progress with it upon our Voyage, yet after the wearying and boisterous winds we have been buffeting it was a real relief. My wife was yet so weak and exhausted that she could not go upon deck till towards Evening.— There was a very large scull of Porpoises, wallowing unwieldy round the ship about Noon; and innumerable multitudes of what the Seamen call Portuguese Man of War, floating along-side the whole day and Evening. One of them was hooked up by Mr Shield. There appeared to be a small cockle shell at the centre with a long sack of a white thin jellyish substance issuing from the hole of the shell, and a very minute animalcule, of the size, and nearly the form of a flea, alive, but implicated in the slime of the jelly, and unable to extricate itself from it. I thought it a sort of marine spider, that the white jelly is a web or net which the animal within the shell spins from its own substance, and puts forth for the double purpose of enabling it to float, near or upon the surface of the water, and of catching its prey. We also saw a tropic bird, & one of those they call mother Cary’s chickens. These, as well as porpoises, are always considered as prognostications of foul weather, but there is upon the Ocean so great a proportion of foul weather, that every natural object that presents itself may justly be considered as announcing it— Fishes, Birds, Clouds, vapours, and nothing more certainly than fair weather itself.— I wrote the greater part of the Morning, yet not so industriously as I ought to have done. Spent most of the afternoon at Chess with Mr Otis. Mr Davis, one of the Steerage Passengers, a Musician, and his Son, who works his passage as Cabin-boy entertained us in the Evening with songs, accompanied by the violin.— Lat 41:43. Long: 30:36. Air and Water 63. It was rumoured that a vessel was seen from the Mast-head this morning; but nothing further of her appeared. We have seen no other vessel since this Month came in.

6. IV:30. Just before midnight last Evening there sprung up a light breeze at North-East which continued all Night and all the former part of this day; it was part of the time fresh enough to carry the ship six knots an hour, but was without steadiness or consistency of any kind. It was shifting from point to point all the morning and soon after died away to a calm— The Ship was as quiet as she ever can be upon the Ocean, and there was no Sea-sickness on board; I wrote part of the morning, and read some pages of Bacon; of Stewart’s Philosophy of the Human Mind, and of Hewlett’s Commentary on the Bible. But of all occupations on board ship, I find reading the most irksome. In the course of the day we saw two ships, one of which stood for us until she came within about four miles distance of us; and fired a gun of which we saw the smoke, but did not hear the report, to bring us too. She had a pendant flying at her Main-mast head, and appeared to be a Sloop of War, but shewed no flag. Our Colours were hoisted, and some Sails taken in, to lay to; when she immediately stood upon the other tack and went off. The other ship was standing to the Southward across our course. She was not within five Miles of us at the nearest. Multitudes of porpoises were seen; and Mr Coit was alert as usual with his harpoon, but without success. Several of the Portuguese Men of War were hooked up— They were in a great variety of forms, many of them curious to the eye and variegated with colours, purple, green and yellow— The lobster formed live insect implicated in the white jelly is common to them all, and when disengaged from it swims in the water with extreme rapidity. But what I took yesterday for a cockle shell at the centre is a soft and apparently excrementitious substance, not more consistent than the jelly that surrounds it. Some of them are in shape resembling the tapeworm, beautifully spotted, and coil themselves round in the water like a sleeping snake— I now think that the insect instead of being their prey, preys upon them. There are sometimes several of the insects in one of the jellies; they are
of various sizes, but all of the same form and species— My wife spent all the latter part of the day upon deck. Our Latitude was 41:20. Long: 31:40. Air 60. Water 61.

7. V:30. A strong breeze at W.S.W. sprung up at about 3. O’Clock this morning; so fresh that the top-gallant sails were taken in, and the topsails reefed. When I rose it was blowing hard, but the Sun was shining, and forming continual beautiful rainbows upon the spray that dashed up from the waves— The ship laboured excessively; I was just able to write before breakfast the journal of yesterday, but from that time could write no more. After breakfast, most of the passengers turned into their births; after a fruitless attempt to read Bacon, I betook myself to my bed for a couple of hours; the wind increased to a heavy gale, until Noon, and then dissolved itself in a copious shower of rain. It fell suddenly calm; and in a few minutes a new breeze started at N.N.W. which continued fresh but moderate, the remainder of the day— The Southerly wind had left us however the legacy of a head-sea, which kept the ship tossing and pitching almost as much as she did during the gale. We shipped water in at the Cabin windows, and were obliged to put in the dead-lights again. I played Chess with Mr Otis both before and after dinner. He also plays much with Dr Tillary, and occasionally with Mr Cutting. A few porpoises were seen this afternoon, and the spoutings of a whale. Some of the Passengers were Sea-sick this morning, but my wife happily escaped. Mr Lamb was very sick this Evening. Dr Tillary is physician general to the ship. No observation this day. Long: 34:10. Air 63. Water 62.

8. V:30. A small breeze all Night, and the whole of this day: generally about N.N.W. so that we kept a course about W. or W. and by N. which still drives us to the Southward; a vessel was seen from the deck early this Morning; and after breakfast another passed within a mile of us to windward; bound to Europe. She might have spoken us, but did not vary from her course. Our Colours were hoisted, and after they were taken down she hoisted a Dutch flag.— Probably she is from some of the West-India Islands. Mr Lamb continued so ill in the Night that Dr Tillary was called up to him about three this morning; just before day-light; much to the Doctor’s annoyance. He said it was to avoid that evil of nightly calls that he had first determined to withdraw in a great measure from practice— Mr Lamb was much better this day. Our dead-lights were again taken out— I employed the Morning with tolerable industry in writing, and from dinner till dark at Chess with Mr. Otis. My wife passed the day upon deck— Lat: 40:42. Long: 36. Air 63. Water 62.

9. V:15. The Night was almost calm, and it continued so all this day. Towards Evening the remnant of a breeze that had held on till then died away so that the vessel would not steer. I found the air by the Thermometer this morning at 64 and the water at 65. By this rise of 3 degrees in the temperature of the water since yesterday, and by the appearance of a quantity of gulph weed, I was convinced that we had entered the current of the gulph-stream Eastward of the Banks of Newfoundland.— There were none of the external incidents which catch the attention of persons at sea— No vessels seen, and even no porpoises or whales, to beguile the tediousness of the passing hour. An internal incident of no pleasant nature was a Scene between Coit the Mate, and Samuel King, one of the Seamen ship’d by Coll. Aspinwall as a destitute Seaman, and of the man sent from Canton in China, as mutineers of the ship Lion— Coit knocked him down, and beat him with a severity that revolted every person on the ship. My wife who was upon deck at the time, was so much affected by it that she fainted, and was brought down to the after Cabin, and put to bed. Coit said the man after resisting his authority, stripped off his jacket and offered to fight him. The man who is unwell, said that Coit ordered him to go up on a yard, and do something that he was unable to do; which he told him— The Captain ordered the man to do what Coit had bidden him. The man said he was not able to do it; and asked the Captain to let the Doctor examine him; and if the Doctor said he was able to do it, he would. Captain Forman did not comply with this request. This affair discomposed the comfort of the Evening, which was otherwise serene and pleasant. I had employed the Morning in writing; and from dinner till dark at Chess with Mr Otis. I also read a few pages of Bacon’s Novum Organum. Most of the other Passengers had amused the time, with pitching dollars upon the deck; which is a very good exercise. Latitude 40:16. Longitude 36:56.— By Mr Lamb’s Chronometer 2 hours 28 Minutes.

10. V: The Night was totally calm, and it so continued this Morning, for two hours after I rose. The weather fine and warm. Air 65 in the shade. Water 67. The Sun, after having as Coit said sat himself in back-stays came out very powerful, so that we had an awning over the deck, great part of the day. About Breakfast time a very light wind sprung up, which gradually freshened to a five knot breeze before Noon, and called for a reef in the topsails at Sunset. Wind about S.W. and with the prospect of a boisterous Night— I read some passages of Bacon, and wrote, great part of the Morning. I had some conversation with Mr Thompson one of the Steerage passengers, who was recommended to me by a Mr Hawkins in London; Thompson is going to America upon speculation; but without having any determinate plan.— He has been a maker of Corn Measures—Bushels and Pecks; and has also worked at making Musical instruments. He says that the dimensions of a round wooden bushel are 8 inches depth and 18 1/2 inches diameter.— There were porpoises seen this afternoon. I passed it at Chess with Mr Otis, giving him first one and then two Castles, which made him more than a match for me. The Steerage debating Society discussed this Evening the question between the comparative merits of Agriculture & Commerce.— I heard part of the debate. Latitude 40:13. Longitude 37:40.

11. V:15. I have lived half a century, and this day commenced my fifty-first year; and with the grateful sentiments to Providence which this and every former anniversary of my Birth-day has justly called forth are mingled those of humiliation which spring from the still recurring question, to what purpose have I lived— A question the more seriously returning this day, from the notice which my fellow passengers obligingly took of it. My wife and children, in their affectionate regard for me, had two or three days ago accidentally spoken of the approach of my birth day, and Mr Davis, the Poet of the Steerage, had written yesterday three complimentary Stanza’s, which he proposed to have sung, with Chorus at their dinner— The verses were sent to my wife, who shewed them to me; and to return the civility sent the Bard a couple of bottles of wine, to cheer the song— Upon this Mr Vail was requested by the Steerage Passengers to write me a Letter of congratulation upon the day; which he did; and I answered the Letter. The Cabin Passengers also complimented me, at our dinner with a toast, and by sending a deputation of Mr Fearon and George to the Steerage company, to invite a deputation from them, to come and take a glass of wine with us in the Cabin. Mr Vail and Mr Davis were accordingly deputed and came; and Mr Gillam at the request of Mr Davis was also invited to come and join him in the song.— After this, and a few other toasts were drank, I returned thanks to all the company for their kind attention and withdrew. They sat about half an hour longer, had a couple more songs and toasts, and then as Davis said adjourned and asked leave to sit again— The ship’s company had also a distribution of grog for their part of the diversion.— The last Night was stormy and the motion of the ship so violent that most of the Passengers lost their sleep. It blew a gale part of this morning from the S.W. and a stiff 7. and 8 knot breeze, Northerly the remainder of the day— About 10 in the Evening, the wind lulled almost to a calm; leaving a head Sea for the ship to tumble and toss over again— I wrote little, but after dinner played two or three games of Chess with Mr Otis. Latitude 40:49. Long: 40:09. Air 68: Water 67.

12. V:30. Another most unquiet and almost tempestuous Night; the ship rolling and pitching so that I scarcely slept an hour the whole Night. Antoine had the Night-Mare, and roused some of the Passengers by a piercing shriek. Towards Morning the wind abated, and the Sea which had been very heavy from the Northwest, while we had the wind at N.N.E. gradually subsided. The day was fair, partly calm, and the remainder with very light breezes at E.N.E. and N.E. In the course of the day we saw three Ships. One steering nearly the same course with ourselves, and which kept in sight, about six miles distant on our larboard Quarter, from ten in the Morning till dark. The second spoke with us just at noon; and Mr Coit the Mate, with Mr Shiel and Mr Cutting went on board of her. She was an English ship, the Ethelred of Bristol, and bound thither from Jamaica. There was a Mrs Lansdown a Passenger on board, who said she was a sister of Captain Angus of the American Navy, and that she had known Mrs Adams in America— She sent her as a present, upon hearing that she had been very ill, a pot of tamarinds and one of ginger preserved. The Captain sent also for the Ladies on board our ship a few Oranges and limes; and Shiel and Cutting bought of the Sailors some Cocoa Nuts, Shadduck’s and Pine-Apples. She has been twenty-seven days out, and has had strong westerly breezes. Last Night while our wind was fresh at N.E. she was running with close-reefed top sails and a gale at N.W. which explains the heavy head sea with which we were buffeted. By her
Captain’s reckoning, the Longitude where we met was 42:16. Our Captain makes it 42:10. We had not lost sight of this vessel before we spied another, which we met and spoke with just before sunset. This was an American, the Susanna of (name of place in blank) Captain Morgan; from New Orleans and last from New-York, bound to Liverpool; out seventeen days, and making her longitude 46:15. Mr Coit and Mr Shiel, went also on board of her, and brought back a roll of tobacco, and two New-York newspapers, and dated 16. and 23. June— They have had North and Northwest winds, and three days ago spoke with an American vessel from Londonderry, bound to New-York, with forty passengers and 67 days out— The Evening was as fine as the day. The Sun sat in a perfectly clear sky, and I passed an hour on deck in star-gazing. Saw very distinctly all the bright and remarkable Stars in the tail of the Scorpion, and many others which for the want of Bode, I did not recognize. Latitude at Noon 40:42. Air 65. Water 67— The loss of sleep last Night, and the time absorbed during the day in our intercourse with the other vessels, abridged my writing so that the day, was to that purpose nearly lost. I played chess after dinner with Mr Otis with various fortune and success. The visit to the Jamaica-man, gave a choice dessert to our dinner.

13. VII:15. The Night was fine, and the ship unusually quiet, so that I obtained a good-night’s rest, and rose this Morning two hours later than usual. The day and evening continued remarkably fine and fair— In the course of the day we saw at different periods two ships and a schooner— I wrote, some part of the Morning, and after dinner, read upon deck, in Hewlett’s Commentary upon the Bible: finished the Prolegomena. There was some Conversation on certain passages in the Bible, into which Conversation I was reluctantly drawn by Mr Romanis. He is not only an unbeliever, but a scoffer at the Scriptures, and indulged himself in sarcasms, until I thought it necessary to vindicate my own opinions, and to give a reason for the faith that is in me. It drew a circle of passengers around us, and Romanis, obviously from deference for me, forbore to press the discussion— The topic of Conversation was changed. Mr Otis likewise is a skeptic in religion; but he avoids shocking the prejudices or deriding the sentiments of those, who differ from him, and believe the gospel. In the Evening I had a further and very serious Conversation with Mr Fearon who is himself a believer; but who seems inclined to explain from natural causes and the ordinary course of Nature particular passages of the Bible, at which shallow cavillers are most ready to peck; without considering that the whole Bible is a perpetual succession of Miracles, from beginning to end; and that if any one of those miracles be admitted it is dealing in trifles to contend about any other. A Miracle is a preternatural exertion of divine power, beyond the comprehension of human reason; and when once the mind has admitted its existence, and acknowledged its own incompetency to judge of it, there is both presumption and inconsistency, in its undertaking again to make its own powers the standard of those of the Deity, and saying thus far shall my acknowledgment of miraculous power go, and no farther. I had also a subsequent conversation with Mr Shiel upon painting and sculpture— Raphael and Van Dyke; the Cartoons and the Elgin Marbles.— Latitude 40:46. Long: 44. Air and Water, both 67. The Captain was much surprized that after keeping his course at N.W. & by W. from Noon to Noon; he had made only four miles of Northing. He concludes there must be a strong current here, bearing us to the Southward. We have had quantities of gulph-weed passing by us for several days, and have picked up several bunches of it, in which were small crabs variously coloured and nearly of the same size.— About an inch in diameter.

14. V: We had all night and through the whole of this day a seven and eight knot breeze, nearly at S.W. Our course has been mostly N.W. and part of the time N.W. and by W. The weather fine and warm. John and Charles bathed this Morning in a barrel of salt-water upon deck. I found by the thermometer this Morning the Air was at 68 and the water 67. As we are drawing near to the Banks of Newfoundland, where the water is much colder, we tried the water several times in the course of the day; but at seven in the Evening it was still at 67. which it has constantly been the last five days— The day was mostly cloudless, but with the hazy atmosphere which usually attends a brisk S.W. wind. In the Evening there was so heavy a fall of dew, that the deck became uncomfortably damp and the passengers all retreated to the Cabins, and Steerage. The deck was as after a shower of Rain— I
I was employed much of the Morning in writing, but the beautiful weather is a temptation to the deck—which I cannot always resist. From dinner time till tea I was playing Chess with Mr Otis; the amusement which makes time pass the most insensibly. We passed by a Brig this afternoon so rapidly that I had not an opportunity to look at her. As we were steering opposite courses, with a Soldier’s wind, favourable to both though passing within a mile of each other she was in sight not more than an hour. Latitude 41:42. Longitude 46:53. New Moon this Morning.— The Captain saw flying fish this day.

15. V: A great change of wind and weather since last Evening. On rising this morning I found it raining with a thick fog, and very cold. The air by the Thermometer at 52 and the Water at 45. twenty two degrees colder than it had been last Evening at seven . These were indications so strong of our being upon the Grand-Bank that we immediately sounded, but found no bottom with 110 fathom of line.— After a heavy rain of two hours, it cleared off; the fog was dispelled, and several of the Passengers saw from the Tops an Island of Ice which was however not discernible from the decks. A Ship was soon after descried ahead, which soon shaped her course towards us until we met— Mr Coit our Mate went on board of her with Mr Shiel and Mr Cutting. Coit soon came back with Cutting, leaving Shiel there— He brought a Canister of Sugar and half a turtle that they had killed this Morning, and asked for a bag of potatoes and some flour which were sent them in return. On Coit’s second return with Shiel he brought back some ginger; but they had no other fruit and could supply us with none of the grain wanted to feed our fowls, which are upon such short allowance that they peck at their Coops to live. It was the Ship Lord Wellington, Captain Roberts, 28 days from Jamaica, (Kingston) bound to London. Her reckoning of Longitude was 48. They had seen no Ice. Sounded on Sunday for the Bank but found no Bottom. Our Latitude this day was 42:39. and by the Captain’s reckoning, Longitude 50:17 but Mr Lamb’s Chronometer made it just three hours and eleven minutes, which with five minutes for the equation of time, comes to a Longitude of 49. This would bring us close upon the edge of the bank, but not upon it. Captain Forman however, is tenacious of his reckoning and says that the Charts lay down the extent of the Bank incorrectly— That South of 43 there is no Bank; or if any, so narrow a strip that it can scarcely ever be hit upon. I wrote a Letter to J. A. Smith, by the Lord Wellington; and several of the other passengers also wrote. About five in the afternoon we sounded again without success.— The water had then risen to 55. our course All day was about W. with a light breeze at N.N.W. and a smooth Sea. Numbers of Mother Cary’s chickens fluttering and flickering about the ship— The Sun sat clear, and the moon about an hour after— No person on board the ship had ever seen the Moon before, on the first day after that of her change— It was about forty hours— I wrote little besides the Letter to J. A. Smith— Read the Tales of My Landlord— Played Chess with Mr Otis after dinner, and conn’d over one of Philidor’s Games with Charles, while my wife was playing whist in the Cabin— I made a set of Chess-men in paste-board for a small board of Charles’s. This is weakness and waste of time; but such is life at sea.

16. VI:15. Immediately after writing that grave reflection, I spent almost the whole of the finest, the most comfortable and most quiet morning we have had upon the passage, in carving a set of wooden Chess-men for Charles’s board. I wrote not the amount of half a page; and read nothing— A brig was seen early this Morning on the Starboard Quarter, steering the same course with ourselves she continued in sight all day, and at about the same distance of five miles. The water and air this Morning were both at 56. Our Ships Courses W. then W. 1/2 N. and after Noon W.N.W. for since the sight of the Ice-Islands from the Tops, for they were not seen at-all from the deck, our Captain has been shy of going any further North; and our Latitude this day was 42:13. Longitude 51:40. by the reckoning. Captain Forman thinks the ship ahead of the reckoning, but by the Chronometer she is at least one degree short of it. The water this afternoon was at upwards of 60. I passed the afternoon at Chess with Mr Otis, and the Evening with Charles. The Ladies made two whist-parties in the general Cabin— There were porpoises seen, and mother Cary’s chickens seen in the daytime and heard in the Evening.

17. VI: On going upon deck this Morning after a very quiet Night, I found the vessel under the foresail only, with all the other sails furled, or aback upon the Mast. There was a moderate breeze blowing at S.W. but a black threatening Cloud at N.W. with thunder and lightening. Soon after came a fog so thick that we could not see twice the length of the ship; and then a heavy fall of Rain for two hours, with distant thunder— The weather cleared up and the Sun appeared shortly before Noon, from which time the day was fair with a very small breeze, varying from W. and by S.
to N.N.W— After the fog and showers of the Morning, the brig which had been in sight all day yesterday again appeared, and at less distance The disposition to communicate together being mutual, our Colours were soon hoisted, upon which she immediately displayed the same Stripes and Stars. We met within speaking distance between two and three O’Clock, and spoke her. Proved to be the Alexander, of Hallowell, Captain Winslow, from Cork, out thirty-six days, and bound to New-York. She has thirty five Irish passengers on board. Saw several very large Islands of ice the day before yesterday. Had no soundings upon the Bank, but four days ago spoke with a vessel, which two days before had sounded and found bottom. Her reckoning makes the Longitude 54:30. which favours Captain Forman’s conjecture that our ship is about a degree ahead of her reckoning which was this day Latitude 42:09. Longitude 53:36. He thinks we passed the tail of the Bank, between Midnight and the Morning of the 15th: when he first sounded— There can however be no question but that we are Westward of the Bank— The air was this Morning at 60. Water 57. Captain Forman invited Captain Winslow to come and dine with us upon green Turtle; but he had dined. He also objected to the proposal of keeping company together that he had been long out and expected to outsail us; which Forman admitted he probably would with a light breeze.— But as we had this day a fresh breeze, and were close upon the wind, we gained perhaps half a mile upon her before dark. Coit the Mate, a thorough Yankey Jack Tar, was stung to the quick by the boast of Winslow that he should outsail us, so that he took the helm himself and steered at least an hour to gain upon her, in which he fully succeeded— I played Chess as usual with Mr Otis, after dinner, and there was an Evening party of vingt-un in the Cabin— I was most of the Evening upon deck. The morning I had employed in writing, and this day brought up the arrears into which this journal had run before our departure from London. The incessant occupation of time the last five weeks had made it utterly impossible to keep pace with it in my journal. I therefore kept short daily minutes, from which I expected to have leisure on board ship to make out the journal at large. So that when we left London, on the tenth of June my regular Journal stood at the 6th. of May.— But as I wished to have no arrears on the Voyage, I left a space of 26 pages from p 184. to 211. to be filled up from the minutes during the arrears, and from the time of leaving London have regularly recorded every morn the incidents of the preceding day. I also began at Alton, the first morning after we left London, to redeem the arrears, and with as much perseverance and Industry as belongs to my Nature, sluggish and idle as it is, have continued with intermissions of every boisterous and every indolent or dissipated day, until this morning when the space allotted to the vacancy was ultimately filled up. But the 26 pages which I had allowed for the 35 days was not sufficient— I was obliged to abridge the narrative of the whole last week that I was in London, and for the last two days had not even space for the short minutes, which I had taken from day to day.— I propose during the remainder of this Voyage, which I still hope may be terminated by the close of the present Month, to add from day to day some notice of incidents which occurred during the last fortnight of my residence at London, and which the narrowness of the space that I had left to fill up the record prevented me from mentioning— Thus I should have noted on the 24th. of May, that as I was going out for one of the morning walks with J. Bentham, I met in Craven Street Mr Chester the assistant Master of the Ceremonies, who told me that the Queen was much pleased with the footing upon which I had placed the subject of the private Audience to take leave of her—and that she would not wish me to take any further trouble: she wished me a prosperous voyage home, and all health and happiness to myself and my family— I desired Mr Chester to reply to Her Majesty by the assurance how much I regretted the cause which had deprived me of the honour of taking leave of her in person, and of my earnest wishes for the speedy and entire restoration of her health. It was the last time I saw Mr Chester, and closed my relations with the ministerial branches of the Royal Family— Of the Duke’s of Kent and Sussex— I was to see and hear something more— Mr Rae Wilson, the Gentleman who introduced me to the Lancaster School in the Borough of Southwark, is in close and frequent correspondence with the Duke of Kent who is now residing at Bruxelles. The Duke in one of his Letters had mentioned me, which I believe was the occasion of his first calling upon me. He sent me a copy of the passage in the Duke’s Letter,
which spoke of me, to which I requested him to return in his answer to the Duke’s Letter something from me, in a like complimentary Style from me; the Duke replied much in the same manner, but more at large and Mr Wilson sent me also the extract of this second Letter. The Duke of Sussex’s polite attentions to me were still more unreserved. It was by his own proposal that he went with me and shewed me the new Bedlam Hospital, and by an odd coincidence it was on the king’s birth-day. He promised then to call upon me and Mrs Adams the next day; but he was accidentally prevented; and came the day after— Mrs Adams and I were both out but Smith received him. He left a copy of his printed Speech in 1812. upon the Catholic Question, as presented to me by himself— His kindness and civility to me have been signal and uniform, from the time of our first acquaintance at Berlin. But he is now in so strong opposition that his friendship itself was the reverse of a recommendation at Court.

18. VI: The Night was again very quiet, and the morning opened with a very light easterly breeze, and the brig our companion half a mile ahead of us. The air was at 65 and the water at 72. shewing that we were in the gulph stream which was likewise indicated all day by great quantities of gulph weed floating alongside of the ship. The wind very soon edged round to West, and once there freshened to a gale, which brought us before Night to close reefed topsails. We had now the satisfaction of getting to Windward of the Brig; but our course was from N.N.W. to N.— I have experienced so much of this wind and weather, west of the Grand-Bank, and approaching the American Coast, that I ought to be fully prepared for it— Our Latitude was 41:36 Longitude 55:28. I wrote all the Morning, excepting the time for one game of Chess with Dr Tillary. All the afternoon I was at Chess with Mr Otis— My wife was unwell; took medicine, and kept her bed all the morning. The afternoon she passed upon deck. In the Evening they had songs in the Cabin.

19. IV:45. Fresh blow the whole Night, with a most uneasy motion of the ship; and from the time of rising I perceived this was one of the days when I should be able to write only a few lines for the occurrences of yesterday; and having slept little in the Night, I was equally disqualified for reading. I passed therefore almost the whole day at the Chess Board— Before and after breakfast with John, and after dinner with Mr Otis, who has so much improved in his skill that he now again contends with me upon equal terms.— The boys bathed this Morning in a large hogshead of Sea Water which had been prepared for me.— The wind which varied no more than from W. to W.N.W. & W.S.W. kept us under reefed topsails all the Morning, and moderated in the afternoon without much abatement of the swell— A brig Eastward bound passed us very rapidly this Morning, and another within an hour after dinner— Our companion the Alexander was in sight the greatest part of the day. In the Evening there was thunder and lightening. Then a North East gale for half and hour and just before midnight a flat and sudden calm, leaving the ship to pitch, and roll as if her Masts would go over.— The Dead-Lights were at my request put in— The air this morning was at 67. Water 61. Latitude at Noon 42:57. Long 56:24. Our course had been about N.W. and we had got out of the range of the gulph stream early this Morning, as appeared by the coldness of the Water.— The wind itself was cold all this day.— Among the omissions of my journal on the 4th: of June, were some of the observations which I made at the Borough Lancaster school, and at Bedlam Hospital. The system of the school appears to me excellent as a saving both of time and expence. It rivets constantly and necessarily the attention of pupils, and teaches in two years as much as is usually learnt in five. It teaches them also to read and write; all very nearly equally well; it multiplies and extends the means of obtaining elementary education, in a surprizing manner and I have no doubt it communicates any given portion of Instruction, at less than one tenth part of the former cost. There are two candidates for the honour of this invention. Joseph Lancaster, a Quaker, and Dr Bell a Clergyman of the Church of England, who first introduced it in a public school at Madras in India. The two systems without being precisely the same are so nearly alike, that there has been a sharp controversy; on the question which took the idea from the other. It would seem that it occurred to them both without communication with each other— But in England the Churchmen took the alarm, because the English Church service was not taught, together with reading and writing. They sat up therefore, a number of Schools on the system of Dr Bell, in which they teach the liturgy with the alphabet, and put down Church and King, in company with joint hand-writing, into the minds of the pupils. These Schools are patronised with profuse liberality by the noble and the wealthy, while the Quaker-Schools are left to struggle along with very little assistance, and upon their own Merits— The
Queen and Prince Regent however have made small subscriptions to them; and nominally to patronize them and the Duke of Kent has promised them a thousand Pounds, when he has them to give. Lancaster himself has become bankrupt and forfeited his character by dishonesty, so that the school has been taken from him, and he is now a sort of vagabond. It is the fashion in England to say that the management of the Bell or as they call it the National school is better than that of the School for all; as the Quakers call their’s because they receive pupils of all religious denominations, while the National school teaches only children of the established Church. I have not seen the National school, and therefore am not competent to compare them together. The difference between them is however admitted to be of little importance. The system I was informed has been introduced at New-York; and it appears to be so well adapted to the management of the town Schools in Boston, that I should wish to see it introduced there.— On my visit to Bedlam Hospital, I was gratified to find more cleanliness and order, and fewer violent patients than in any similar institution that I had ever seen before. There was a great and manifest improvement in the Hospital upon what I had seen there in 1783. There are now no raging Patients— The Duke of Sussex however remarked at one place that the construction of the door to some of the cells, that they might be used for suicide— Upon which Dr Munro spoke of the constant, unremitting attention they were obliged to pay, in order to prevent that act, by many of the patients.— The Duke called for some of the bread and cheese and Beer like that in common use for the house; which we tasted, and found very good. One of the Patients however complained of the fare; and said it was not so good as in Newgate.— Mackenroth who is a German, had books and materials for writing in his apartment; and appeared tranquil, and conversed rationally with the Duke, Margaret Nicholson, who is now 80 years old had no appearance of madness, but did not utter a word— But there was with her an old Negro woman whose tongue ran without ceasing. She told the Duke she knew him very well; he was the Lord Mayor— There was one general circumstance which I thought yet left room for improvement. Not one of all these wretched persons was occupied— On one table we saw an old pack of Cards with which some of them appeared to have been playing: but most of them were walking to and fro in the long Entries, each in solitude, without any thing to excite his interest or attention— Whether it would be possible to employ them I cannot say, but in the state of total idleness, with confinement for life in which they are kept, it is not surprizing that they should need so many precautions to preserve them, from the violence of their own hands.

20: VI:30. The Calm, and the swell and the rolling of the ship continued through the Night; and my bed had been so made that every time the ship rolled it shifted sides under me, between the partition of the State-Room and my wife’s birth.— Just at Day-light there was some abatement of the rolling, and I obtained a couple of hours of sleep. The Morning was so totally calm that the ship would not obey the helm. The weather sultry— The Sun potent.— Occasional very light breezes in the course of the day, tempered the heat of the Sun, and it became cloudy early in the afternoon. It was American dog day weather, and I had a dull head-ache, and a difficulty of breathing which ceased only when a shower of Rain came up in the Evening. The Morning air was at 72. Water 67. Longitude at Noon 57. Latitude 42:35. A turtle was seen on the surface of the Water near the ship this Morning—great quantities of gulph-weed floated by.— A fry of very small fish, and Mother Cary’s Chickens almost in flocks.— Every one found it necessary to resort to thin Cloathing.— I passed the Morning at writing, and after dinner read in Hewlett’s Commentary on the Bible. The Evening rain excluded me from the deck, and the heat of the front Cabin, where many of the passengers were crowded, induced me to retire to bed about nine O’Clock— All was then quiet; but just at Midnight there came on the most sudden and most violent Squall of rain and wind that we have yet had upon this passage. All the Sails were as speedily as possible taken in; not without damage to them and to the rigging, and for half an hour she was scudding under bare poles. The sky soon cleared away and a bright Northern light was seen. Many of the Passengers during the Squall were much alarmed. All the waking were affected with some degree of agitation. Captain Forman who was upon deck had Mr Coit immediately called up; and the bustle and turmoil, and running to and fro of the Sailors and shrieking clamours of the orders to hand the sails, were as appaling as I have usually known them on similar occasions. I had for my own part all day expected such a termination of it, with the addition
of thunder and lightening— No change of wind followed this bourasque. It stuck about W.S.W— Our progress the last two days has been scarcely anything. Brig Alexander in sight the whole day.— Additions to my Journal of 5. June— This was the day upon which by agreement the Sunday before with Lord Castlereagh, I was to have called for the last time upon him. But I received a Note from him requesting me to postpone the meeting with him until the next day the 6th: and then to call upon him at the Foreign Office in Downing Street— I had at a former Meeting enquired of him whether it was customary to furnish foreign Ministers who have resided at this Court with a Letter of recredence. He then told me that there was one for me, before the Prince Regent for his signature, and which as soon as it should be signed, should be sent to me— I mentioned it again on Sunday 1. June, and desired that if it should not be ready until after my departure it might then be sent to Mr Smith who would forward it to me. Lord Castlereagh’s Note now informs me that the Prince Regents Answer to the Letter from the President of the United States which I delivered to him, has already been transmitted to Mr Bagot: so that no Letter of Recredence was furnished to me at all.— It was while I was out on the visit to the Borough school that Mr Wilberforce called at my lodgings, and wrote there a Note mentioning his wish to see and converse with me before I should leave England and also his desire of introducing to me his brother in Law Mr Stephen.— I answered the Note, agreeing to meet him, and Mr Stephen, at Downing Street, at 2 or 3 O’Clock the 6th:— But although my Note was left on his table, he did not take it up, the whole day of the fifth, nor until after I had called two or three times at his lodgings. I therefore missed of seeing Mr Stephen altogether and only met Wilberforce with Babbington— On the 5th. also, I received from the Committee of the Borough School a Note with a printed Volume containing an account of their Institution, and of all the Schools connected with it—

21. IV:15. After the furious Midnight Squall, the wind settled again at W.S.W. a fresh breeze, and there adhered all day with occasional intervals when it edged on to W. & W.N.W. The morning was clear, but soon afternoon it clouded over, the wind blowing with menace, of a gale— We had the two inner dead-lights taken out, but there is such a constant recurrence of heavy weather that we thought it best to leave the Starboard Quarter dead-light in for the remainder of the voyage— That of the Larboard Quarter has already been in this Month. The air this Morning was at 67. Water 58. Towards Evening the Thermometer was again tried. Air 62. Water still 58. The Captain supposes we are upon the Porpoise Bank. Latitude at Noon 42:57. Longitude 58. Porpoises, Mother Cary’s Chickens and the Brig Alexander were seen. I wrote, most of the Morning; and read in the Novum Organum and Tales of My Landlord. From dinner time, passed the afternoon at Chess with Mr Otis, and in the Evening, while my wife and the other Cabin Passengers were at Cards, Charles and I were playing over Philidor’s first game to teach Mr Cooke the Elements of the game.— The wind abated much after Sunset, and towards Midnight came to the North and sunk to a light breeze the sky clearing away, when I retired to bed— Additions to my Journal of 6. June, the day of my Conversation with Mr Wilberforce and Mr Babbington in Downing-Street. There had been published in the London papers of 4. June a Resolution of the Congress of the United States, passed at their last Session requesting the President to enter into Negotiation with Great-Britain and other European Powers, for completing if possible the suppression of the Slave-trade, and for sending certain free people of Colour from the United States to Sierra Leone or some such Settlement on the Coast of Africa. Wilberforce, intimated to me, but did not expressly assert that he had not seen this Resolution till after he had written me the Note in Craven Street, requesting to see me; and he said he had been gratified at the coincidence— But the great object of his wish to see me was evidently to start the proposition that the British Cruizers against the slave trade should be authorized to overhaul and search and even capture American Vessels, suspected to be engaged in that trade. Probably this project originated in the brain of Master Stephen, the Author of War in disguise and brother in Law to Wilberforce. One of the party called in derision, the Saints, and who under sanctified visors, pursue worldly objects with the ardour and perseverance of Saints. Wilberforce is at the head of these Saints in Parliament, and is said to possess more personal influence in the House of Commons than any other individual. Lord Castlereagh has more than once thrown out this idea of a mutual stipulation that the cruizers of every Nation which has passed laws for abolishing the Slave-trade should be authorized to search and capture the Slave trading vessels of the other Nations by whose Laws the trade is prohibited. In substance it is an impudent and barefaced attempt of the British to obtain in time of Peace that right of searching and seizing the ships of other Nations, which they have so outrageously abused during War. I never discussed the subject with Castlereagh, because he never brought the point to an explicit proposal, and it was not necessary to sift the proposition to the bottom, but Wilberforce after much lamentation at the inefficacy of the existing laws and measures for suppressing the trade, and
asserting that it was now carried on with as much activity and inhumanity as ever; professed to be unable to devise any thing that should effectually suppress it. And yet he said there was one thing that would accomplish the end; if the Nations would agree to it—and then came out with the proposal, and enquired whether the United States would agree to it. That all vessels, whatever Nation’s flag they should bear, but which might be suspected of being engaged in the slave trade, should be liable to search and capture by the Cruizers of any other Nation. I told him I thought there would be some objection to this. In the first place, No American vessel engaged in the Slave-trade, could use the American flag; for the trade was prohibited by Law; and a vessel which should be captured while engaged in it Could not obtain any interfence of the American Government to rescue her. The flag could be no protection to her. The Commander of the capturing vessel would only act at his peril: and if he seized a vessel, not really concerned in the trade, he must be responsible to indemnify the sufferer. Again, a stipulation of this nature though nominally reciprocal would be really one-sided— Cruizers against the Slave-trade are in fact kept only by Great-Britain— British vessels therefore would be liable to no search or capture, but by Officers under the authority of their own Government; while the vessels of other Nations would be subject to seizure by foreigners not amenable or accountable to their own Sovereigns. Some degree of prejudice must also be supposed to exist against the naval Power of Great-Britain, and particularly some jealousy of the exercise of an arbitrary power by her Naval Officers. Mr Babbington appeared to admit there was more foundation in these objections than Wilberforce was ready to allow. He suggested that in each Cruizer there should be an Officer of each Power agreeing to the principle, and that he should be present at every search, and no capture to be made without his consent. I objected to this that it would lead to conflicts of opinion and perhaps even of authority between the Officers of the different Governments, and Wilberforce did not like this expedient any better than I did. I also alluded to the misconduct of many naval British Officers; to the manner in which they had taken Slaves from the United States, and had probably sold many of them; and I explained the manner in which the judge of the Vice-Admiralty Court had evaded the British Statute and Order in Council, by which captured slaves were to be liberated or rather made the King’s Slaves for life— Wilberforce was much struck by this information, of which I authorized him to make such use as he thought proper.— He somewhat equivocally expressed his disapprobation of Admiral Cochrane’s Proclamation, inviting the Slaves to run away from their Masters and join him; and said he knew too much of what had been the lot of those Slaves. He added that there were very few of them in Halifax,— I believe that Wilberforce was on the whole disappointed in the result of this interview, though we parted in perfect good humour and civility.— I mentioned that Mr West, with Zerah Colburn and his father spent the Evening of 6. June with us. Mr West then told me that he had in the year 1783 made a sketch for a Picture of the Peace which terminated the War of the American Revolution, which he would send me to look at the next Morning, as he accordingly did. I then recollected having seen it before, at the time when my father was sitting to him for his likeness in it. The most striking likeness in the picture, is that of Mr Jay— Those of Dr Franklin and his Grandson W. T. who was Secretary to the American Commission, are also excellent— Mr Laurens and my father though less perfect resemblances are yet very good. Mr Oswald the British Plenipotentiary was an ugly looking man, blind of one eye, and he died without leaving any picture of him extant. This Mr West alledged as the cause which prevented him from finishing the picture many years ago. Caleb Whitefoord the Secretary of the British Commission is also dead; but his Portrait exists from which a likeness may be taken. As I very strongly expressed my regret that this Picture should be left unfinished Mr West said he thought he could finish it; and I must not be surprized, if some day or other it should be received at Washington. I understand his intention to be to make a present of it to Congress. Zerah Colburn’s father urged me to let him communicate to me the secret of his instinctive arithmetic. I consented, and he made the attempt but without success. I might perhaps have understood him; but for the continual interposition of the father himself who without understanding it, by his frequent explanatory interruptions disconcerted both Zerah and me— I was however satisfied that the secret is only a rapidity of intellect with which the boy performs the process of multiplication and division, and that it is communicable only to minds equally quick in their operations.

22. VI: The Night was nearly calm, and when upon rising this morning I went upon deck, I found the ship was heading South, uncontroulable by the rudder. Immediately after came a breath of a head breeze, and Coit the Mate was deliberating whether he should have the Steering sail taken in or not. He had laid a wager with Dr Tillary, last Night that there would be two hours of Easterly wind in the Night; and the Steering-Sail was his proof that he had won the wager. At last he took in the Sail, but left the boom out, till the Doctor came upon deck. The day was fair, & the Evening the most beautiful we have had upon the passage— The Moon which quartered yesterday, shone, almost in conjunction with Jupiter, but with a faint and distant Halo, portending foul weather— Her beams playing with picturesque beauty on the Waters which were barely ruffled to a three knot breeze. I remained until ten upon deck, and then retired to my Chair Bed. I had devoted the Morning to writing, and the Novum Organum; and from dinner till dusk to Dr Tillary, Mr Otis and the Chess-Board. A Brig Eastward bound passed us in the Morning, and a ship towards Evening. But we have entirely lost sight of the Alexander.— Air 65. Water 67. Latitude 42:53. Longitude 58:47.—Additions to my Journal of 7. June.— J. Bentham walked with me to the corner of St. James’s Square, where Lord Castlereagh’s house stands, and when I went in agreed to wait for me, walking up and down the Street, ten minutes: if I should be detained longer than that he was to go home, and if on coming out from Lord Castlereagh’s I had still time for a walk, I was to call for him at his house. I was with Lord Castlereagh about half an hour. His project of offering the Mediation of Great-Britain, to settle the differences between the United States and Spain, surprized me much; after what had passed at Ghent. But his plan of bounding us by the Mississippi, was exactly what I should have expected from a British Mediator— Castlereagh had in the first instance very cautiously spoken of the scheme of Mediation, as being merely an extra-official idea of his own, and now he did not seem to expect much from it. As to the Mediation of the allies between Spain and Portugal he told me the substance of the latest communication from the Court of Rio Janeiro which had already been told me by Count Palmella— The only difference that I perceive between the two Statements is that Palmella told me the explanations given by his Government of the occupation of Montivideo, were communicated before they had received the offer of Mediation, and therefore was altogether uninfluenced by any impressions from Europe— Castlereagh said the explanations were given before the offer of Mediation was received; but after the Court of Brazil was informed of the first impressions in Europe, (meaning England) by the movement against Montevideo. Intimating that England had taken some step to call for explanation, before that general one of the allies. With respect to the Spanish South American Insurgents Castlereagh was not altogether explicit, but rather evasive in regard to the probable future policy of England— All that could with certainty be collected was that she will intermeddle as much as possible— That she will side to the utmost extent she dares against the Insurgents, but without proceeding to direct hostilities against them, and serving herself by urging Spain to allow them a free trade, at least with the English. In all her Mediations or offers of Mediation her justice and policy will be merely to serve herself. Count Lieven was waiting in the Antichamber to speak with Castlereagh while I was with him; and when we went into the antichamber to look at the map, Castlereagh asked Lieven to go into the Room from which we had come— Lieven looked anxious of knowing what we were about. He afterwards called at Craven Street, but I had not returned home, and did not see him. Both he and Poletica several times hinted to me, a desire to know how we stood with Great-Britain, and a suspicion that there was a prospect of early hostilities between them. They have some indistinct idea of the question and discussion concerning the fisheries, and have the expectation that it will terminate in a War— When I left Castlereagh’s it was too late for the walk with Mr Bentham; and instead of going to his house I called upon his friend Place the Taylor, and Republican. He keeps a shop in Charing Cross, and is quite prosperous in his trade, notwithstanding his dabbling with politics. Place who was unwell received me in his library two pair of Stairs up from his shop. He had a very considerable library, all the shelves of which that I noticed were full of Books of History and Political Economy. He told me he was very glad, I had rejected that ridiculous proposal of Sir Richard Phillips’s to set up and pay for an American Newspaper in London.— Place asked me where he could procure a volume of the Constitutions of the United States; and I promised to send him one. I had given mine to Bentham— Place was much interested about a man named Wooler a printer who had just been tried for a libel upon Lord Castlereagh and Mr Canning in a weekly periodical publication called the Black Dwarf. Wooler was tried at the Old Bailey, before judge Abbott of the King’s Bench. He pleaded his own cause, and astonished a crowded auditory by his Eloquence— He was tried upon two informations upon both of which the Judge strongly charged the Jury against him— One of the Jurymen of the first jury asked the judge what
they must do if they found the matter charged as libellous, true. He said that by the Law, truth was no justification of a libel. The jury were out several hours without being able to agree— There were three Talesmen who stood out for the defendant against nine special jurors, still more stiff for the Crown. At last the Talesmen agreed to a verdict in this form “As truth has been declared to us to be by Law a libel, we of the Jury are compelled to find the Defendant guilty.” but they stipulated that if the Court refused to receive the verdict in that form the jury should go out again.— Instead of this verdict Abbott the judge, ordered a general verdict of Guilty to be recorded, and refused to receive the affidavit of the Talesmen, as to the agreement about the terms in which the verdict was to be delivered. The next day upon a statement of the facts by Abbott himself in the Court of King’s Bench, Lord Ellenborough in a manner compelled Chitty whom Wooler had in the meantime employed as his Counsel, to say that he asked for a new trial, and immediately granted it. Subsequently however Chitty moved that the Defendant should be discharged, which motion still remained to be argued when we left London. Bentham told me that it was a general opinion among the lawyers that Abbott had lost his reputation by his conduct on this occasion. He also told me that if a vacancy should occur in the Election for Westminster, it was intended to set up Wooler as a Candidate— Place told me that if Wooler had not argued his own cause he would certainly have been convicted. That no lawyer would have dared, or been suffered to put the cause upon its real and strong point of defence. That Lord Ellenborough, by his overbearing and brow-beating controul over the bar, had annihilated the Spirit of all the lawyers. That if any lawyer had a pretension to Independence, Ellenborough would harrass and persecute him, till the suitors found out he was not well with the Court; and then, no soul would give him a brief. He had in this manner ruined the practice of Brougham and many others. Place said he had often served as a jury man in Courts where Ellenborough presided, and had seen much of him; but never without having his most vehement indignation excited by his despotic and insolent controul over the lawyers. In all causes of mere property between man and man he was an able and upright judge; but in every case where the Court had an interest, he was an unprincipled and unblushing despot and oppressor; and they had rewarded him for it by making him a privy Counsellor— It was somewhat curious that after receiving this character of Ellenborough, Smith and I were on the same day received by him, when we went our round of official visits.— We were also received by Sir Joseph Banks, whom I saw for the first and last time— I mentioned to him Lieutenant Percival’s new invented pump box for ships at sea, and recommended it to his attention, if there should be an application concerning it to the Board of Longitude of which he is President. He said he thought it would probably not be within the Province of the board of Longitude; although they readily examined many objects relating generally to Navigation: but he promised every assistance in his power to Lieutenant Percival if he should apply to him concerning his invention, whether as President of the Board of Longitude or in any other capacity. I mentioned to Sir Joseph how shamefully F. Pursh had abused his confidence and mine by drawing bills for money upon my brother on the pretence that I had funds of his in my hands— He said Pursh had treated him in the same manner— On calling at Mr W. W. Pole’s, as neither he nor his Lady were at home, I left a message, that my wife was so unwell we should not be able to go there this Evening according to the invitation we had received, but that we would call again if possible before leaving town. After finishing the visits with Smith, I called at Bentham’s merely to tell him I would walk with him to morrow Morning. He already knew that I had been with Place— After dinner I called at Dr Bollmann’s lodgings to see him, but he was not at home. There was a civil Engineer named Upton who called upon me, and was very desirous of going to the United States— The Letters which he shewed me from Latrobe and John Spear Smith were of encouragement and invitation founded upon the appropriation by the Legislature of Virginia, for making new Roads and Canals.— The same object upon which Governor W. C. Nicholas wrote to me, and upon which I had recommended W. Couling. Upton had received his Letters only a few days since though they were dated I think a year ago or more. I have never received from Governor Nicholas any reply to the proposals of Couling, which I sent him by duplicates more than a year since— I told Upton that I had recommended another person to the Governor of Virginia for this
employment, upon which he said he could not go to the United States upon an uncertainty, and would wait until he should hear something further— Received a Letter from my Mother. A Note from Mrs Copley to say that the Pictures were ready to be delivered, whenever they may be sent for by Coll. Aspinwall— A note from Mr West with a Letter for the President of the United States, and a present to my wife of his portrait, on the medal struck in honour of him. We sent back his sketch of the Picture of the Peace of 1782.— A note from Lord Castlereagh with a Passport for myself and my family, and Letters from Coll. Aspinwall, mentioning that he had effected the Insurance upon all my furniture & baggage by the Ship Washington, to New-York, and thence in another Vessel to Washington City at 2. per Cent—which Letter I answered— A Letter from Mr Hawkins recommending to me a Mr Thompson, who is going as a Steerage passenger with us in the ship. There came also a Letter from one of the boys at Dr Nicholas’s school to George, asking him for two books which he had lent him, and which must have been by mistake packed up with ours— I wrote a Letter of Instruction to J. A. Smith upon leaving the Affairs of the Mission in his charge— Among the Letters received was one from a Mr Da Costa, by a special messenger on Horseback who was directed to wait for the answer. It was to say, that Mr Da Costa, having very important documents to communicate to me respecting the recent revolution in Brezil, requested me to appoint a time when I could receive him— If I was gone he wished to make the communication to Mr Smith. I answered, appointing to-morrow, at one O’Clock to see him.

23. V: I was waked soon after daylight, by a very heavy shower of Rain, and when it was over found the weather almost calm with a thick fog. The ship however kept upon the whole her course from Noon to Noon. Latitude 42:44 Long: 60:56. Air 67. Water 63— But the wind never deviates long or far from W.S.W— It was there by Noon, and soon freshened, till it became necessary to reef the topsails. The Head-Sea, very soon succeeded, and before I had finished my writing for the day, the pitching of the ship made it so uncomfortable, that after finishing two pages I was obliged to leave my task for the Morning unfinished. I attempted to read in the Novum Organum but after a few pages found the book dropping from my hands by drowsiness— The hour for dinner was at hand; and from dinner till dusk I was at Chess with Mr Otis. This pastime is a trial of temper to which mine is not always adequate— I this day gave Otis a Castle and he beat me two games out of three. When I lose the game it is generally from some neglect or oversight of mine so gross and glaring that it mortifies my pride beyond endurance— I sometimes lose the calmness of my disposition, to a degree bordering upon rudeness; a single blunder throws me so completely off my centre that I scarcely ever can redeem the game, after it— I also find myself committing the same oversights time after time, and one defeat proves no lesson to guard against another. There is a capacity of combinations in Chess which is a painful test of intellect.— It occupies the understanding and works upon the feelings too powerfully for sport.— The Evening was fine, and before ten I left them at Cards in the Cabin— Additions to my Journal of 8. June— It was the last Morning walk that I took with J. Bentham, and we went as usual through Hyde Park, and Kensington Garden. The written questions upon the state of religious opinions in America, and particularly upon the effect of avowed deism or atheism upon a man’s reputation and influence in Society, with the answers I had given to them formed the principal subject of our Conversation. I perceived that my answers were not exactly such as he would have desired. He spoke with more reserve than usual, as if unwilling to shock prejudices which he had found rooted in my mind. The general tenor of his observations however was to discredit all religion, and he intimated doubts of the existence of a God. His position was that all human knowledge was either positive or inferential— That all inferential knowledge was imperfect, and uncertain; depending upon a process of the human mind which could not in its Nature be conclusive— That our knowledge of the physical world was positive; while that of a Creator of it was inferential— That God was neither seen, nor felt, nor in any manner manifested to our senses but was the deduction from a syllogism, a mere probability from the combinations of human reason.— That of the present existence of matter we have positive knowledge— That there was a time when it did not exist we assume without proof, for the purpose of assuming equally without proof an eternal creator of it— I observed in answer to it that inferential knowledge was in numberless cases more to be relied upon than what he called positive knowledge; meaning the mere testimony of the senses. That our knowledge of physical nature such as it is, consists entirely of inferential corrections of the testimony of the senses.— While we trust the positive knowledge of the senses, we must believe that the Sun, and the whole firmament of Heaven move daily round the Earth; and so stubborn are these cheating senses that after they have been convicted of imposture, and when we know it is the revolution of the Earth round its axis, that produces all these phenomena, we persist in saying that the Sun, Moon and Stars daily rise and set, and it is only when we sit down to astronomical calculations, that we discover the truth—the triumph of inference over the senses.
I said that the proofs of intellect in the operations of the material world, were as decisive to my mind, as those of the existence of matter itself. Intellect not residing in matter, but moulding and controuling it. What is that intellect, and where is it? Every where in its effects— No where perceptible to the sense.— That this intellect is competent to the creation of Matter, I know, not from reason but from Revelation—but that it modifies and governs the physical world is apparent both to my senses and my reason. He replied little to this argument, apparently because he saw that my opinions were decided, and he did not wish for controversy. He said however that Place was a professed atheist— From the general tenor of his part in this Conversation, and from several incidental remarks of his upon other occasions, I consider him as entertaining inveterate prejudices against all Religions, and that he is probably preparing a book against religious establishments. If he had found my sentiments congenial with his own, I have no doubt he would have disclosed his sentiments more fully— He spoke to me this day of an Estate in Pennsylvania, in the inheritance of which Mr & Mrs. Koe, are interested indirectly. There is a nearer relation who wished to employ an Attorney in the business and he asked me to recommend one— I mentioned S. Ewing— I agreed, if Mr Jump the person interested would come to me to-morrow, to authenticate a power of Attorney, to Ewing, and another with the name in blank, in case Ewing should decline to accept the trust— After returning from the walk, several visitors came to Craven Street, among whom was Mr Da Costa with his documents from Brezil— One was a copy, together with a translation, of a Letter to the President of the United States, from Jonõ Ribeiro Pepoa, Domingo Jose Martino and Manuel Correa de Aranja styling themselves the Patriots Provisional Governors of the Province of Pernambuco— It is an appeal to the sympathy of the United States, and a call for assistance from them— It charges the House of Breganza with the design of assassinating more than 600 respectable heads of families, on the suspicion that some of them were free-masons.— Mentions their Manifesto, of which there is however no accompanying copy, and declares that the Revolution was accomplished in 14 hours with the unanimous concurrence of Brazilians and Europeans, and with no bloodshed, except of 16 unfortunate satellites of despotism. The Letter is dated 12. March last, and purports to be sent by Joseph Bryan, a Citizen of the United States— The other document was copy of an Ordinance issued by the same provisional Government of Pernambuco declaring the Ports open to the Merchant vessels of all Nations, and permitting the importation of provisions and warlike stores, free of duty for one year. I took these papers; but Dr Bollmann and Poletica, were present, all the time that Da Costa was with me, and I was not desirous of having any particular conversation with him— He had no material information other than that which is public. Poletica was inquisitive about the state of affairs between the United States and England, about which he said the British Government were affectedly close and reserved. I told him there was nothing to be reserved about. He muttered something about the fishery— I told him there was a question between us about fisheries; as I heard there was between Russia and Sweden, about a fishery on the Coast of Norway. This diverted the Conversation into another channel. Dr Bollmann said something to me again of himself; and suggested the usefulness that it would be of to the United States to keep in Europe constantly a scientific agent, who might collect and transmit the earliest information of all discoveries in Science; improvements in the Arts, and useful inventions. He said the Emperor of Russia, had constantly two such persons in London. Bollmann is a man of strong genius with weak judgment; an ardent imagination, and an unsteady character. He might be exceedingly useful if he could be safely trusted.

24. IV: I Rose at this early hour, chiefly for the purpose of seeing the Sun rise clear, which is at Sea, one of the sublimest, and most beautiful objects in Nature. I enjoyed this sight in all its glory. The air was at 67. water 65; with a fresh breeze at N.W. and a swell sufficient to cause an uneasy motion of the ship— Brig Alexander in sight the whole day. I wrote until breakfast, soon after which the wind blew so hard and the vessel heaved so heavily, that after an ineffectual attempt to resume writing I gave it over for the remainder of the day. Hence the present intermission of the additions to my Journal for the last days before we left London— I then attempted to practice one of Philidor’s Chess-games with Charles till sea-sickness compelled him to leave the table. Our Course was about S.W. which with variation of the compass and
lee-way was little better than due South— Latitude 41:44. Longitude 61:25. Afternoon with Mr Otis and Dr Tillary, at Chess. Towards Evening the wind died away almost to a calm— A scull of Porpoises seen. I remained upon deck until ten, and then turned in for the Night leaving the Cabin occupied by three whist parties.

25. VI: The Sun rose this Morning not perfectly clear, and I kept my bed later than usual. When I rose there was not a breath of wind. The brig was in sight. Air and water at 73 and the Sun coming out intensely hot. The sky however indicated that the calm would not last long— Before breakfast a light breeze sprung up, which came for an hour or two from the South; but soon came to the point of W.S.W. and then very shortly freshened to a gale.— Until an hour after noon, it was so moderate that I was able to write, and I improved the time as well as I could— The motion became so violent however nearly two hours before dinner that I was obliged to lay aside my pen, and have recourse to the Tales of my Landlord— All the afternoon the gale was blowing in successive Squalls of increasing violence.— It was with great difficulty that Mr Otis and I occupied the Chess-Board, and we left it earlier than usual. The wind itself was hot, and the Sun shining till the close of the day. The Moon was bright all the Evening, with scuds of black Clouds passing with extreme rapidity over her face— Lightening was constantly flashing from deep black clouds to the leeward. The heat drove the passengers from the Cabin upon deck; and the dashing of the spray drove them back again to the Cabin. Latitude 40:56. Longitude 62.53 Brig Alexander in sight all day: rather gaining upon us from being able to carry more sail.

26: V: About eleven last Evening I threw myself half undressed upon my bed, and lay till between one and two this morning quite sleepless, when the heat became insufferable, and I rose and went upon deck. I found Mr Shiel there with the Captain— The gale had not abated but continued blowing in squalls of increasing fury. The moon was still shining, and the part of the horizon from which the wind blew, scarcely looked cloudy. But heavy scuds of clouds were flitting constantly over the face of the Moon and Stars, and deep flashes of forked lightening, were ranging round from N.E. to Southwest.— I remained upon deck till near three, when the Captain ordered the Spanker and mizen topsail to be taken in; when a Sea broke on the windward Quarter, and dashed over me such a sprinkling of the Spray as drove me down again to the State-Room.
