The Main Sail and fore topsail were then taken in and the Main-topsail close reefed.— Our deadlights had been put in just before bed time last Evening.— At five O’Clock I rose again, and upon deck found the ship under the Fore-Sail, close-reefed Maintopsail, and Main and Mizen Stay-Sail with no others— Coit the Mate was stretched out dozing on the hen-coop; and Jack Williams the Seaman at the helm told him there was a black squall to windward that looked very dangerous— Let it come, said Coit; the sooner the better. We are ready for it. This formidable cloud however parted into two, and went off in heavy showers one on our Starboard, and the other over Larboard Quarter— We had nothing of it— The Sun soon afterwards came out, and exhibited a glowing Morning Rainbow; about seven in the Morning a Cloud passed over from which fell a little rain— It was followed by a succession of others moving more and more copiously for three or four hours— From the first fall of Rain the violence of the wind began to subside, and it gradually abated after every shower; before Noon there was barely wind left to fill the sails. The air and water had both been up last evening to 78. this Morning they were at 73— There was no Observation at Noon— Longitude by the reckoning 64:07. The middle dead lights were taken out again this Morning. The swell of the Sea, was less than might have been expected from the force of the wind; which the Captain ascribes to the current of the gulph stream in which we are, flowing in the same course with the wind. While we were at dinner the wind came North of West, and before dusk it was at East, and our Steering sails were rigged out— Showers of Rain still pouring down— A flying fish fell upon deck, at the dusk of the Evening.— It was the twentieth Anniversary of my Marriage day; noticed by a toast given by Dr Tillary after dinner.— The Brig Alexander was in sight until the change of the wind in our favour, where she kept her course W. and by N. while we kept ours at W— Another brig steering also westward was seen in the course of the day. The extreme weariness, which followed a Night like the last disabled me from writing more than the yesterday’s Journal. I put up my Books immediately after breakfast, and could barely get along with the Tales of My Landlord. From dinner till dusk I played at Chess with Mr Otis.— Additions to my Journal of 9 June— I have mentioned that the Ship Washington left the London Dock on the 5th. with my Sons John and Charles, my Servant man Antoine, and the Cook-maid Mary Newell, whom we call Ellen, on board.— Captain Forman, and my Son George with Mr Otis and Dr Tillary went the next day, and embarked at Gravesend. I remained with my wife and Lucy Hauel her chambermaid, at London; having agreed to join the ship at Cowes. Captain Forman had promised to write me from the Downs, to give me notice when to leave London; we heard on Sunday that Captain Forman had the evening before returned from Gravesend to London— He had forgotten to take with him the order from the Custom-house for the clearance of my effects— He therefore went to London for it; returned with
it the same night to Gravesend, from whence he sailed on Sunday Morning the 8th. He did not write to me as he had promised from the downs; but our preparations for departure being all made we determined to proceed without waiting any longer— We had first ordered our Post-Chaise and Horses, for four O’Clock afternoon of the 9th. but it rained all the latter part of the day, and we finally concluded to start from Craven-Street at Noon on Tuesday the tenth— The day of Monday was absorbed in packing Trunks; settling Bills; writing a final despatch for the Department of State; making up my account, and writing Letters to Coll. Aspinwall, J. Maury and S. Williams; with a Note to Lord Castlereagh, mentioning one of my Notes to him that is unanswered, and which was accidentally omitted from the minute I had left with him on the 7th. Mr R. Jump came with Mr Koe, and executed a power of Attorney to S. Ewing, and another in blank, for the business of which J. Bentham had spoken to me— Bentham himself sent me some melon-seeds for Cincinnatus Adams, my father, and came and took leave of me— As we parted he said significantly to me that he shouldpray for the safety and prosperousness of our voyage; and I answered him in the same tone— “And the prayer of the righteous man availeth much—” Burt, the inventor of the patent log for sounding was present; and being a religious man was much struck with the manner in which we both spoke; but he did not know all that either of us meant. J. Winthrop came and left a Letter with me, requesting that I would read it at my leisure. It was a very urgent solicitation for appointment to some consular Office which might in all respects suit his convenience. Zerah Colburn’s father came and asked my advice what to do with his Son’s portrait, and how he should procure subscriptions in the United States for his book— I advised him to send the Picture, not as he hinted he inclined to do, to Congress; but to the Academy of Arts at New-York; and for his subscriptions, I advised him to go and solicit them in the United States himself; leaving Zerah here, at Westminster School— He said he believed he would go to America next year— The trials of the Spencean philosophers for high Treason, commenced this day at Westminster Hall; before the Court of King’s Bench. They excited a great sensation among the public: but I was too much occupied with my own affairs to attend at the Court. N.B. I have now completely brought up the arrears of this Journal, which during my last residence in Europe, and most especially from the time when I left St. Petersburg to attend at the Negotiation of the Peace of Ghent, has occupied so large a portion of my time that I can henceforth no longer continue it with the same minuteness— On my return to my native Country, a new, and for some time at least a busy and laborious scene threatens to open before me— A Scene so laborious, and so full of perils and perplexities, that a stouter heart than mine would be appall’d at the prospect of it— From the time of my arrival in the United States, my Journal must be a mere abstract of loose Memoranda— My whole time must be devoted to the performance of duties, and may the Mercy of Heaven assist me duly to discharge them!

27. VI:45. The light Easterly breeze continued through the Night and all this Morning. A Dolphin was caught, by a hook baited with the flying fish that fell on board last Evening, which gave us a mess of fresh fish at breakfast. It was four feet long from the snout to the end of the tail, and weighed twenty pounds. Another Dolphin was swimming along side of the vessel, and was hooked from the bow, but by its weight broke from the hook, and would not bite again. A Shark, three floating barrels, and a bale were afterwards seen in the course of the Morning. I employed it in writing. A Solar rainbow was visible in the Morning, and a lunar one in the Evening— Air 73. Water 76. Latitude 41:13 Longitude 65:25. But since we spoke the Brig Alexander whose reckoning of Longitude was West of ours, we have been daily making more Longitude than I have thought our courses and the log would warrant— This Evening just after dusk we spoke with the Schooner Caroline of Freeport, from New-York to St. Michael’s; out six days, and making her Longitude 61:30. Captain Forman asked if they were sure of their reckoning, and was answered they were confident of being not far out of the way. He was however still confident of his own, and took a wager of a beaver hat with Mr Lamb, that it would prove when we come on soundings that our reckoning was nearer being correct than that of the Caroline— The afternoon and Evening had a threatening aspect of impending squalls, with distant thunder and Lightening— I read in Hewlett’s Commentary, and finished The Tales of My Landlord.

28. VII: The Night passed off very quietly, and this day was fair and moderate; but the wind got back to its old point of W.S.W. and kept our course at N.W— The air and water were both at 77; proof decisive that we are yet in the current of the gulph stream— The Deck was great part of the day uncomfortable by the heat of the Sun, and the Cabins by the confinement of the Air.— Lassitude disqualified me for writing; I read something of the Novum Organum and a part of one of Miss Edgeworth’s new Comic Drama’s. Latitude 48:42. Longitude, by Coit’s reckoning 68:12. but if that was correct, we should have soundings and cold water. The Captain himself is now convinced that the reckoning has overshot the ship— I suppose our real Longitude this day to be 63:30— A vessel Eastward bound was seen this afternoon— I spent it at Chess with Mr Otis— Cards were played in the Cabin this Evening, but I passed it upon deck in Conversation with Mr Fearon.

29. VI: After a quiet Night this morning commenced with heavy showers of rain succeeded by thick fog, and a flat calm; from which there was afterwards little variation— Air at 72. Water 66. Having before breakfast written my journal of yesterday, and finished reading the Novum Organum, I wasted all the remainder of the day—the Morning in playing over Philidor’s Queen’s Gambit game, with John and Mr Cutting, and the afternoon in losing five games of Chess and my temper, with Mr Otis.— The Brig Alexander was in sight the greater part of the day. The children hooked up quantities of gulph weed loaded with barnacles, and one parcel with a small crab— After dinner the Captain sounded, but found no bottom. At the same time two experiments were made with an empty bottle— The first time it was corked with a long and very large cork, the neck then dipped in tar, and then a piece of thick canvass tied closely over and round it. the bottle was tied to the lead used for sounding, and sunk, between sixty and seventy fathom deep in the water. When brought up, the cork was found forced through the neck into the belly of the bottle; the canvass cap distended, and forming a small tunnel depressed half an inch into the neck of the bottle, which was full of water that had strained itself through the Canvass. The second experiment was of corking up the same bottle, empty, placing over the cork and the neck of the bottle an English half-penny which was sealed upon it with sealing wax— It was sunk again with the lead, and when brought up, the cork was again found forced into the bottle; but the half penny remained in its place sealed over the neck of the bottle which was nevertheless full of water— These experiments were made at the suggestion of Mr Cutting who said he had seen them made before with the same results. The water brought up in the bottle was by the thermometer about five degrees colder than that of the surface along-side of the ship. The Evening was serene and beautiful, but calm— They had Cards in the Cabin. Latitude by reckoning 41:09. Long: 68:20.

30. IV:30. The Night was again calm, and the morning fine. I saw the Sunrise, and took a cold bath in one of the water hogsheads filled with the Sea water. There was not wind enough for the vessel to steer. A couple of hours afterwards a light breeze sprang up; at W.S.W. forcing us to a N.W. course— Air and water both 66. Latitude 41:25. Long: 69: but that is within 30 miles of the Longitude of Boston, and would be in sight of land. The day was fair, and the Sun warm. I finished reading the Novum Organum, and began de Augmentis Scientiarum. Chess after dinner with Mr Otis, more successfully than yesterday. After Sunset came on one of those heavy South West gales which have visited us almost every third day, this whole passage; it soon brought up a wearisome swell, and before midnight a copious rain. At Midnight the Captain sounded but found no bottom. The Dead-lights were put in by direction of Mr Coit, after I had retired to bed. They had Cards in the Cabin.

31. IV:30. It was the most tempestuous Night we have had upon the passage; of which I had some expectation from the dark clouds flashing with lightening to the leeward of the ship, the brightness of the Stars above the horizon, and the shooting of several of those atmospheric meteors commonly called falling Stars. Great part of the Night the ship was scudding under close reefed top-sails with the wind baffling between S.W. and W— By the tossing and pitching of the vessel, my bed was sliding under me, so that I scarcely slept an hour the whole Night. When I rose I found the weather had moderated. The air was at 64. but feeling very cool. Water at 70. importing that we are yet within the verge of the gulph-stream— A brig Eastward bound passed within sight of us before Noon. Our Latitude was 41:36. Reckoning Longitude 69:40. but really about 64. The day was moderate and cool, but a heavy swell all the Morning, and the weariness which always succeeds a sleepless night prevented me from writing more than the journal of yesterday. I passed
the afternoon from dinner till dusk as usual at Chess with Mr Otis, and had various success. Read the Preliminaries of the Treatise De Augmentis Scientiarum— As the tediousness of our voyage increases with its length the recourse of the other passengers to card playing becomes more frequent. Yesterday they had loo all the afternoon; and this day, they had it morning afternoon and Evening— I find my passion for Chess encroaching upon me in the same manner— Towards Evening the wind, came round, a very light breeze at N.E. and our Steering Sails were set. It soon became too cool for the deck, and I turned in, shortly after nine— Inner Deadlights were taken out this morning.

Day. I Rise on the average between five and six, and immediately go upon deck where I ascertain with my thermometer the temperature of the air and of the Water drawn from the side of the ship. Then return to our after cabin, and write my journal until the time for breakfast; about nine. From ten till half-past two I write again, when the weather permits; or read; with occasional intervals of going upon deck to look at a sail in sight or at porpoises or whales or any other of the few objects from abroad which excite a momentary notice— The dinner table is cleared off about four, from which time till the dusk of Evening I play Chess with Mr Otis; or an occasional game with Dr Tillary— They have tea and supper at eight, from which time the remainder of the Evening in the Cabin is given to Cards; at which I have taken no part. When the weather admits I remain upon deck, walking, or star-gazing, or conversing with one or another of the passengers until ten or eleven when I retire for the Night. This is the regular course, subject to many exceptions— A Stormy Night which to me is always a sleepless one, is always followed by a languid and idle day. A heavy swell seems to throw a sort of confusion upon the faculties of the mind and disqualifies me for writing or reading. The heat of some of the late days has produced a similar effect, and made me waste even the Mornings in idleness.— When we embarked at Cowes, this was the term at which I had hoped our voyage would close— We have now a prospect of being from five to ten days more at sea. The number of passengers that we have on board gives a certain liveliness and variety to the scene; but the longing for land is universal, and the calls for Patience grow daily more urgent and more irksome. We have yet abundant cause to be thankful.
